This Risk Management Plan (RMP) is submitted by General Chemical Bay Point Works in compliance with the requirements of section 112[r][7] of the Clean Air Act (CAA) and was prepared in accordance with United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) regulations contained in 40 CFR Part 68, Accidental Release Prevention program.

The Accidental Release Prevention program requires the owner of a stationary source having listed substances present in quantities greater than the corresponding threshold quantities to develop and implement a risk management program. The program must consist of a hazard assessment, a release prevention program and an emergency response program. Additionally, the operator must describe the site's risk management program in a risk management plan (RMP). However, the regulation provides for three different programs of compliance dependent upon eligibility criteria of covered processes including, but not limited to, the potential impact of chemical release as identified in the hazard assessment. For example, chemical processes which meet the criteria for program level 1 and program level 2 have very minimal requirements for release prevention programs and emergency response as compared to those for program level 3.

At General Chemical - Bay Point Works, four listed chemicals are managed on site in quantities greater than the threshold quantity under the program level 3 criteria. No chemicals are managed on site under program 1 or program 2 criteria. The chemicals managed according to program level 3 include Anhydrous Ammonia, Aqueous Ammonia (>20%), Anhydrous Hydrogen Fluoride and Hydrochloric Acid(>30%). As identified in this plan, Bay Point Works is in compliance with the requirements of 40 CFR part 68 for management of Anhydrous Ammonia, Aqueous Ammonia, Anhydrous Hydrogen Fluoride and Hydrochloric Acid.

Section 3.0 - The worst case release scenario and the alternative case release scenarios

3.1 - The worst-case scenario as defined by the USEPA is a hypothetical accident for one of the chemicals at the site. It assumes that all safety systems in the facility simultaneously fail and that all of the chemical in the largest container holding it at a site is released in a very short time. USEPA-designated table defines the distance the material will travel until it disperses so much that it is no longer hazardous.

The worst case release scenario at General Chemical - Bay Point Works assumes that a rail car containing Anhydrous Hydrogen Fluoride fails, and the content are released in 10 minutes. The USEPA-designated table states that the material released would travel 25 miles before it reaches a non-hazardous concentration.

3.2 - The alternative case release scenario is a more credible hypothetical, site specific chemical release. It takes into account safety and release prevention systems and procedures used at the plant to control releases. It is more realistic than the worst case release scenario. It is used to plan a facility's emergency response to accidents.

1.0 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

General Chemical ¿ Bay Point Works is committed to being a responsible member of the community. General Chemical's Corporate Policy dictates that facilities minimize the potentia

l for adverse effects to the environment as well as to the health of employees and local citizens by operating plants safely. This commitment to safe and environmentally sound operations is documented in the corporate policy and compliance procedures that are available to all employees.  General Chemical ¿ Bay Point Works stresses safe and environmentally sound operations in the employee training programs and in written materials available to employees.  As a method of promoting compliance with applicable federal, state and local environmental, health, and safety regulations, General Chemical performs routine corporate audits. Bay Point Works is typically audited annually via this program. Methods of minimizing or reusing wastes, in addition to using energy and materials wisely, are encouraged. We are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes in a safe and responsible manner. We use accidental release prevention programs to make sure our processes are managed safely, as well as to comply with regulatory requirements such as OSHA¿s Process Safety Management, USEPA¿s Risk Management Plan and Contra Costa County¿s Industrial Safety Ordinance. However, if a release does occur, we have prepared our personnel and local emergency response groups to respond accordingly.

Section 4.0 - Process Description for Ammonium Hydroxide Manufacturing

Anhydrous Ammonia is delivered to Bay Point Works by tank truck and pumped into a 12,000-gallon storage tank. A vapor recovery line is connected between the tank truck and the storage tank in order to recover any displ

ed water and hydrofluoric acid produces the 40% ammonium fluoride solution. Hydrofluoric acid is produced at Bay Point Works and a description of that process is provided in Section 6.  This procedure is performed in two separate vessels at Bay Point Works. Temperature control valves in the bottom tank are used to control the rate of reaction. The ammonium fluoride solution is circulated through a heat exchanger/cooler in order to maintain a low reaction temperature. The top tank operates on the same principle.

Section 6.0 - Process Description for Hydrofluoric Acid Manufacturing

Anhydrous Hydrogen Fluoride of 99.99% purity is delivered to Bay Point Works primarily via rail car. Rail cars are pressurized with nitrogen and unloaded into a purge pot to be sampled. Following laboratory approval, the railcar is unloaded into one of two Anhydrous Hydrogen Fluoride storage tanks. The Anhydrous Hydrogen Fluoride reactor is charged by the pressurization of the storage tanks with air to deliver material into the reactor. Once in the reactor, the Anhydrous Hydrogen Fluoride is treated and steam heated. Anhydrous Hydrogen Fluoride vapors enter the absorption column and are scrubbed with deionized water, forming electronic grade hydrofluoric acid (49-70%).  Electronic grade hydrofluoric acid is then sent to the Packaging Area for packaging into totes, drums or bottles and the Batch Area for use in a wide variety of different blends of products and/or the Ammonium Fluoride process.

Following the completion of a batch,¿ an aqueous hydrofluoric acid heel remains in the reactor.  This material is nitrogen transferred from the reactor to the heel tank. The heel is then transferred to the aqueous hydrofluoric acid storage tank, which is then transferred to railcars.

The vents from the railcar unloading, purge pot, storage tanks, Anhydrous Hydrogen Fluoride reactor, and heels tank are run through a primary and secondary scrubber system. The liquid from these scrubber systems is p

umped to the aqueous hydrofluoric acid storage tank. A pressure relief system protects the Anhydrous Hydrogen Fluoride vessels from over pressurization.

Section 7.0 - Process Description for High Purity Hydrochloric Acid Manufacturing

Hydrochloric Acid is received in railcars, and is off loaded into the feed storage tanks using an unloading pump. The Hydrochloric Acid is analyzed and the impurities are treated prior to use. The process takes place in one glass column and one polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) lined column to remove non volatile impurities.

Hydrochloric Acid is fed to the Hydrochloric Acid units via a common pump. The feed tanks are vented to a scrubber to prevent process vapors from entering the atmosphere.

The Hydrochloric Acid enters one of the two columns and flows counter current to the rising vapors. Two tantalum bayonets supply heat to the process. The vapors are condensed at the tip of the columns by two glass product condensers at 37.1 to 37.4% concentration. The uncondensed vapors also flow through a cooler before they are vented to the scrubber. Appropriate vents are installed in the system to relieve pressure build up and minimize tailings. All vents are tied into the scrubber. The water from the scrubber flows into the waste neutralization tank and is discharged in accordance with the POTW permit. Product is transferred to storage tanks.

Section 8.0 - The general accidental release prevention program

General Chemical maintains a comprehensive release prevention program designed to prevent accidental releases and ensure safe operations of our processes. The accidental  release prevention program implemented at Bay Point Works includes procedures and practices which address each of the required elements of the risk management program including:

- Process Safety Information - Information relating to the hazards of the chemical(s), process technology and equipment information is maintained to ensure proper operation.
- Mechanical Integrit

y - Equipment is routinely inspected and maintenance activities are managed in a manner to maintain the integrity of the equipment.
- Process Hazard Analysis - Processes are routinely analyzed to identify and correct potential hazards, as well as increase the safety of the operating conditions.
- Standard Operating Procedures - Detailed procedures are in place identifying actions necessary for mulitiple phases of operation, operating limits and safety considerations.
- Employee Participation - Employees at all levels are involved in key roles of the release prevention program.
- Training - Employees in the operating process are trained in detail to ensure proper operation of the plant.
- Management of Change - Process parameters are maintained through a management of change system which documents the changes as well as evaluates changes for safety.
- Pre-startup Safety Review - Significant changes to the processes are evaluated in detail in order to verify that the proper procedures for engineering, operations, emergency response and overall safety are addressed prior to start-up.
- Incident Investigation - All incidents are investigated to ensure proper modifications are made to reduce or eliminate the potential for re-occurrence.
- Safe Works Practices - Standard safety practices are in place to help ensure worker safety including lockout/tagout procedures, control of entry into process areas, line breaking procedures, confined space entry procedures and hot work procedures
- Contractor Safety - Contractors are evaluated and trained prior to performing work on-site to reduce the potential of an incident.
- Compliance Audits - PSM/RMP audits are performed at a minimum of three-year intervals to verify procedures and practices are adequate and are being followed
- Emergency Response - Plans are made with the community emergency response groups as well as on-site emergency response teams to ensure procedures are in place in case an emergency situation occurs.

In add

ition to this general accidental release prevention program, General Chemical Bay Point Works has taken additional chemical-specific prevention steps designed to perform the following:

- Quickly detect a release of an extremely hazardous substance;
- Contain or control a release of an extremely hazardous substance;
- and/or, reduce the consequences of a release of an extremely hazardous substance.

The following types of safety features are used in various processes:

Release Detection:
- Process temperature and pressure controls
- Motion detectors, with automatic shut-down to control potential releases from railcar movement
- Sensors for early vapor release detection
- Operator surveillances of all process areas
- Remote video monitoring of process areas

Release containment and Control
- Pressure relief devices and pressurized storage units and process vessels
- Secondary containment for storage units
- Check valves on unloading systems
- Automatic and manual shut-down systems on process equipment
- Water fog equipment

Release Mitigation
- Emergency shut-down procedures
- Trained emergency response personnel
- Notification procedures for plant personnel and local officials
- Personal protective equipment for emergency response personnel
- Emergency response plans prepared with local emergency response officials

Section 9.0 - The five year accidental history

Due to proactive actions taken to prevent accidents and the strong safety culture developed by General Chemical Bay Point Works, there have been no incidents in the past 5 years that meet the reporting requirements for the USEPA's Accidental Release Prevention Provisions.
